questions.text: Which of the following structure doesn't  pass through the foramina marked in the diagram below:
questions.solution:
The marked foramen is foramen ovale and the middle meningeal artery does not pass through this structure. Middle meningeal artery passes through the foramen spinosum.

The greater wing of the sphenoid presents a crescent of foramina of which only the foramen ovale and spinosum are visible when viewed from the basal aspect. The foramen ovale lies medial to the foramen spinosum. It transmits the following structures:

  • Mandibular division of trigeminal nerve (V3).
  • Accessory meningeal artery, a branch of the maxillary artery.
  • An emissary vein that connects cavernous venous sinus to pterygoid plexus.
  • Lesser petrosal nerve

Related Pearl: Structures passing through skull foramina

Opening Transmits
Optic canal Optic nerves and ophthalmic arteries
Superior orbital fissure First (orbital) division of the fifth, and the third, fourth and sixth cranial nerves, superior orbital
vein and a branch of the middle meningeal artery
Inferior orbital fissure Infraorbital nerve and infraorbital artery and the inferior ophthalmic veins
Foramen rotundum Second (maxillary) division of the fifth cranial nerve
Foramen ovale Third (mandibular) division of the fifth cranial nerve and the accessory meningeal artery
Foramen spinosum The middle meningeal artery
Foramen lacerum No large structure completely traverses through it.
Carotid canal Internal carotid artery.
Jugular foramen Inferior Petrosal sinus, Cranial nerves IX,X & XI and Sigmoid Sinus that continues as IJV as it passes the foramen.
Hypoglossal canal Twelfth (hypoglossal) cranial nerve
Foramen magnum

Medulla oblongata, along vertebral and spinal arteries and veins, and the spinal root of the eleventh cranial nerve

questions.text: A 30-year-old athlete injures his leg. He complains of pain in his knees. The following technique has been employed to alleviate his pain. Choose the false statement regarding the mechanism behind this technique.

choices.text: Operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.
Based on the inhibition of pain pathway in the spinal cord.
Local lateral inhibition of interneurons occurs in the spinal cord.

questions.solution:
The given image shows transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief. It is based on the gate control theory of pain. This method uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibres (not inhibition) near the injury to relieve pain.

Gate control theory is based on the inhibition of pain pathways in the spinal cord. Various sensory inputs from a particular dermatome reach the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. The pain is transmitted via A-delta and C fibers, whereas, A-beta fibers carry tactile sensations (touch, pressure) and A-alpha fibers carry proprioception.

When these large-diameter A-beta/A-alpha fibres are stimulated, they inhibit the pain pathway in the spinal cord. This inhibition is thought to result from the local lateral inhibition of interneurons in the spinal cord.

Gate control theory operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

The given image depicts the gate control theory of pain:

Related Pearl: Types of mammalian nerve fibres (Erlanger and Gasser's classification)

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male with untreated Hepatitis B presents with flank pain and gross hematuria. What is the light microscopic findings of renal biopsy in this patient?

His Lab investigations are as follows:

  1. Serum LDH - increased
  2. Gross proteinuria
  3. Presence of multiple RBCs with normal morphology and no casts
  4. Presence of anti-PLAR antibodies.

choices.text: Diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane with spikes
Tram-track appearance of the glomerular basement membrane
Mesangial widening and deposition of IgA

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of renal vein thrombosis that is common in patients with nephrotic syndrome, especially membranous nephropathy, as in this patient.

Histopathology of membranous nephropathy is diffuse thickening of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM).

Renal vein thrombosis

  • Thrombo-embolic complications in nephrotic syndrome are due to the loss of endogenous anticoagulants (e.g., antithrombin III) in urine.
  • Acute RVT most commonly presents due to trauma, severe dehydration, or a generalized hypercoagulable state. Typically presents with flank pain, gross or microscopic hematuria, marked elevation in lactate dehydrogenase, and increase in renal size on imaging. Bilateral RVT presents with AKI. 
  • Chronic RVT is insidious in onset and usually occurs in patients with long-standing nephrotic syndrome.

Image: Pathophysiology of the nephrotic syndrome

Membranous nephropathy (MN):

  • Notable associations of this condition include drugs (penicillamine, captopril, NSAIDs), underlying malignant tumours, SLE, chronic Hep B, and Hep C
  • Anti-phospholipase A2 receptor antibodies are seen in most patients with MN
  • On light microscopy, the glomeruli exhibit uniform, diffuse thickening of the glomerular capillary wall
  • On electron microscopy, there is an appearance of spikes protruding from the GBM, which are best seen with silver stain
  • Immunofluorescence shows granular deposits of both complement and Ig
  • During the advanced stages, the glomerulus may become completely sclerosed

The image below shows the light microscopic findings in MN. 

Other options:

Tram-track appearance of the glomerular basement membrane (Option B) and crescentic appearance of the glomerulus (Option D) are seen in membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis, a type of nephritic syndrome. Red cells in the urine would be dysmorphic in this condition and there would be a presence of red cell casts.

Mesangial widening and deposition of IgA (Option C) is seen in IgA nephropathy

Related Pearl: Nephrotic and nephritic syndromes

 

Nephrotic Syndrome

Nephritic Syndrome (Glomerulonephritis)

Primary pathology

Damage and dysfunction of glomerular filtration barrier, causing significant leakage of plasma proteins without much glomerular inflammation

Significant inflammatory injury of the glomerulus resulting in passage of RBCs, inflammatory cells & plasma proteins

The principal site of glomerular injury

 Visceral epithelial cell (Podocyte) Endothelial cells, glomerular basement membrane (GBM), Mesangial cells, Parietal epithelial cells (>Crescents)

Clinical features

Hallmark:

Heavy Proteinuria: 3.5 g/24 h or Urine protein:creatinine ratio >3) 

Hypoalbuminemia, 

Edema

Lipiduria, Hyperlipidemia

Microscopic hematuria

Hypertension

Hypercoagulability                                                    

Hallmark:

Hematuria (RBC casts/dysmorphic RBCs)

Varying degrees of proteinuria and pyuria

Renal dysfunction

Hypertension

Associated Glomerular pathology

Minimal change disease (Primary and secondary)

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) (Primary and secondary)

Membranous-nephropathy (Primary and secondary)

Diabetic nephropathy

Amyloidosis

Acute post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (crescentic)

IgA nephropathy (Berger disease)

Membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis

Alport syndrome

These syndromes, however, are not mutually exclusive. Some glomerular diseases may progress from one pattern to another or may present with considerable overlap between them, as a nephritic–nephrotic syndrome; features of nephrotic syndrome can concurrently occur with any form of nephritic syndrome but are most commonly seen with diffuse proliferative glomerulonephritis (seen in systemic lupus erythromytosus) and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis.

Related Pearl: Glomerular Pathology in Renal Diseases

Disease

Electron microscopy

Nephritic syndrome:

Postinfectious glomerulo-nephritis

Diffuse endocapillary proliferation; leukocytic infiltration

Granular IgG and C3 in glomerular basement membrane and mesangium, 

Granular IgA in some cases

 

Subepithelial humps (between the basement membrane and overlying epithelial cells) Subendothelial deposits in early disease stages

Goodpasture syndrome

 Extracapillary proliferation with crescents; necrosis  Linear IgG and C3; fibrin in crescents

Linear deposits of immunoglobulins along the basement membrane. 

Disruptions in GBM

 Normal Negative Basket-weave appearance of GBM

Nephrotic syndrome:

Membranous  nephropathy

Diffuse capillary wall thickening

Granular IgG and C3; diffuse

 

Subepithelial deposits (epimembranous spikes), effacement of podocyte foot processes.

Minimal change disease

Normal; lipid in tubules

No deposits.

Effacement of podocyte foot processes.

Focal segmental glomerulo-sclerosis  (FSGS)

Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis

 Occasional C3 and IgM deposits in the sclerotic areas and the mesangium.

No deposits.

Effacement of podocyte foot processes.

Epithelial denudation.

Nephrito-nephrotic syndrome:   

Membrano-proliferative glomerulo-nephritis

(MPGN) type I

Mesangial proliferative or membrano-proliferative patterns of proliferation; GBM thickening; splitting

IgG ++ C3; C1q ++ C4

 

Subendothelial deposits

Dense-deposit disease (MPGN type II)

Mesangial proliferative or membrano-proliferative patterns of proliferation; GBM thickening; splitting

C3; no C1q or C4

 

Intramembranous Dense deposits

Fibrillary glomerulo-nephritis

  

Membrano-proliferative or mesangio-proliferative patterns

 IgG4 and C3  Fibrillar deposits in the mesangium and glomerular capillary walls

 

Note:

  • Anionic antigens form subendothelial deposits.
  • Cationic antigens form subepithelial deposits.
  • Neutral antigens form mesangial deposits.

 

Image – Linear, smooth diffuse pattern of staining for IgG in Goodpasture syndrome:

questions.text: Which of the following disease is not transmitted by the arthropod given below?
questions.solution:
The arthropod in the given image is Aedes mosquito due to its stripped body.

West Nile fever is transmitted by Culex mosquito. 

Diseases transmitted by Aedes:

  1. Yellow fever (Option B)
  2. Dengue
  3. DHF
  4. Chikungunya (Option C)
  5. Rift valley fever (Option D)
  6. Filariasis
  7. Zika virus

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution.
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes and Mansonia.
  • Flight range varies up to 11 kms, except Aedes for which it is 100 metres.
  • Life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days.
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen.

Charateristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia
EggsUsually 100-250. This stage lasts 1 – 2 days. Laid singly; boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star shaped clusters.
Larval stageThis stage lasts for 5 -7 days.

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Stripped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artifical collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis,Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 
  • Called "Nuisance mosquitoes"
  • These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called as tiger mosquitoes and they are day biters

They get the"tiger" name from white stripes  on its legs.

 Mansonia mosquitoes are big, black or brown mosquitoes with sparkling on their wings and legs. 

 

 

  • Culex mosquito, they keep their bodies horizontal while feeding:

 

  • Anopheles mosquito as seen in the image below, they tend to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high:

 

  • Aedes mosquito (aegypti), as seen in the image below, their bodies are striped:

questions.text: Which of the following drugs act via the mechanism depicted in the illustration shown below?
questions.solution:
The given illustration shows the G-protein-coupled receptor pathway for signalling. The drugs that function via this mechanism is Dobutamine.

OTHER DRUGS that function via this mechanism:

  1. Propranolol
  2. Atropine
  3. Misoprostol
  4. Montelukast

Functional families of GPCRs include beta-adrenergic receptors, muscarinic cholinergic receptors, eicosanoid receptors, and thrombin receptors.

G proteins act as inhibitory and excitatory because of differences in the alpha subunit.

In general, Gs and Gq subtypes are excitatory whereas Gi is inhibitory.

Resting-state:

  • G protein heterotrimer consisting of alpha, beta and gamma subunits forms a complex with G-protein-coupled receptors at the intracellular domain. The extracellular domain of GPCR has the binding domain for hormones and G protein subunits do not directly bind them. 
  • The alpha subunit is bound to GDP 

Binding of ligand results in an activated state: 

  • Alpha subunit undergoes a conformational change
  • Release of GDP and binding of GTP
  • GTP bound alpha subunit dissociates from beta-gamma subunit
  • Both alpha subunit and beta-gamma subunit bind to and regulate effectors only when they are separated 

The illustration below shows the pathway.

Other options:

  • Interferon acts through cytokine receptors, which belong to the structural family of transmembrane, non-enzymes.
  • Imatinib acts via the receptor tyrosine kinases, which belongs to the structural family of transmembrane enzymes.
  • Verapamil acts via the voltage-gated ion channel.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Malignant otitis externa?

choices.text: Technetium 99 bone scan is used to monitor the disease.
Perform radical surgical debridement and resection.

questions.solution:
Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa is an infective condition and not malignant condition. Hence, mitotic figures will be normal.

Malignant (necrotizing) otitis externa:

  • Pseudomonas infection in the elderly diabetics and  those on immunosuppressive drugs.
  • Excrutiating pain, profuse discharge & granulations on the floor of EAC.
  • Necrosis of bone aids in spread of infection.
  • Facial paralysis is common. (Option A)
  • Infection may spread to the skull base and jugular foramen causing multiple cranial nerve palsies.
  • Gallium-67 is more useful in diagnosis and follow-up of the patient
  • Technetium 99 bone scan reveals bone infection, but test remains positive for a year or so and cannot be used to monitor the disease. (Option B)
  • Treatment:
    (i) Diabetic control.
    (ii) Ear toileting
    (iii) Antibiotic treatment against causative organism(P. aeruginosa) for 6–8 weeks or more.
    • Antibiotics found effective are:
      • Gentamicin combined with ticarcillin. (intravenous)
      • Third-generation cephalosporins combined with an aminoglycoside. (intravenous)
      • Quinolones combined with rifampin. (oral) 
If patient is not responsive, culture and sensitivity of ear discharge should be done.
Prolonged antibiotic treatment has replaced radical surgery and resections done earlier for this condition. (Option D)

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presents with a history of injury to the eye caused by a leaf 5 days ago, resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. His eye is as shown below. Which of the following is not a feature of the hypopyon present in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical situation suggests that it is a fungal corneal ulcer. Fungal keratitis causes a non-sterile hypopyon.

Unlike bacterial ulcer, the hypopyon may not be sterile as the fungi can penetrate into the anterior chamber without perforation. Aspergillus spp. are the most common cause.

A hypopyon consists of polymorphonuclear leucocytes which accumulate in the lower angle of the anterior chamber and eventually become enmeshed in a network of fibrin. It is clinically seen in severe corneal ulcers as a collection of ‘pus’ in the anterior chamber.

Hypopyon in a fungal ulcer:

  • Non-sterile
  • Thick and Fixed
  • Contains fungal filaments

questions.text: A study was conducted on the effectiveness of aerobic exercises for weight loss. The study was done between two groups (one as control group and the other as test group) to measure their body weights after 1 month of aerobic exercises. Which of the following tests would be appropriate to compare these two groups?
questions.solution:
The test of choice to measure the difference in means between two groups in a study, with one group being a control is Unpaired T test.

In this scenario, two groups are being compared hence, Student's t test/ Unpaired t test will be used. If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups are being tested, or more than 2 groups.
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

The tests:

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember paired test is mainly used in comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Which of the following presents with hypokalemia + metabolic acidosis ?
questions.solution:
Diarrhoea presents with hypokalemia + metabolic acidosis.

Diarrhoea causes non anion gap gastrointestinal bicarbonate loss, resulting in metabolic acidosis and the loss of potassium resulting in hypokalemia.

Other options:

  • Option B: Vomiting results in hypokalemia + metabolic alkalosis
  • Option C: Nasogastric suction results in hypokalemia + metabolic alkalosis
  • Option D: Conn's syndrome (primary aldosteronism) results in hypokalemia + metabolic alkalosis.

questions.text: A 35 year old woman  presented with retrosternal chest pain radiating to the jaw and dysphagia.She also complaints that the symptoms are exacerbated after drinking a glass of cold water or any cold drinks. Barium swallow findings of this patient is shown below. Manometry in this patient will show_________

choices.text: Decreased amplitude of oesophageal peristalsis <30 mmHg
Peristaltic oesophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal

questions.solution:
The above clinical picture and barium swallow showing a corkscrew appearance are characteristic of a diffuse esophageal spasm (DES). Manometry in diffuse oesophageal spasm will show simultaneous multipeak contractions >120mmHg.

Diffuse oesophageal spasm:

  • Barium swallow: Corkscrew or rosary-bead esophagus, segmental spasm or pseudodiverticulosis appearance is seen. It is due to the presence of tertiary contractions. It is indicative of advanced disease.
  • Manometry findings: Simultaneous, multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 sec). These erratic contractions occur after more than 20% of wet swallows. There is intermittent normal peristalsis.

Related Pearl: Manometric findings in oesophageal disorders

Manometric Findings in Nutcracker Esophagus

  • Peristaltic esophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal
  • Amplitude > 180 mmHg and duration > 7seconds.
  • Normal peristaltic sequence

Manometric Findings in Diffuse Esophageal Spasm

  • Simultaneous, multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 sec)
  • These erratic contractions occur after more than 20% of wet swallows.
  • Intermittent normal peristalsis

Manometric Findings in Hypertensive Lower Esophageal Sphincter-

  • Elevated LES pressure > 26mmHg and normal relaxation of LES
  • The esophageal body may be hyper-peristaltic or normal.

Manometric findings in Achalasia Cardia

  • Incomplete LES relaxation
  • Aperistalsis in the esophageal body
  • Elevated LES pressure ≥26 mmHg
  • Increased intraesophageal baseline pressures relative to gastric baseline

Manometric findings in ineffective esophageal motility disorders

  • Decreased or absent amplitude of esophageal peristalsis (<30 mmHg)
  • Increased number of non-transmitted contractions

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents for a routine antenatal checkup at 20 weeks of gestation. On abdominal examination, the uterine size was found to correspond to 16 weeks of gestation. On USG, oligohydramnios was found. Which of the following is a likely cause?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, renal agenesis seems like the likely cause of oligohydramnios. It causes oligohydramnios in the early second trimester.

Fetal urine production starts between 8-11 weeks of gestation but becomes a major component of amniotic fluid only in the second trimester. Thus, oligohydramnios is not seen until after 18 weeks of gestation in fetuses with lethal renal abnormalities.

Neural tube defects, Bartter syndrome and Chorangioma of placenta usually lead to polyhydramnios and not oligohydramnios.

Related Pearl: Causes of oligo and polyhydramnios

Causes

Oligohydramnios

Polyhydramnios

Maternal

Post-dated pregnancy, Pre- Eclampsia, NSAIDs, ACE inhibitors, undiagnosed rupture of membrane (most common)

Spontaneous rupture of membranes

Diabetes, cardiac & renal diseases, liver failure

Fetal

Fetal anomalies, Renal agenesis, urethral defects (posterior valve, obstructive uropathy)

 

Neural tube defects, open spina bifida, anencephaly, abdominal wall defects, cleft palate, neck masses, aneuploidy, hydrops fetalis, twin to twin transfusion syndrome, multiple pregnancies 

Placental

Failure of secretion:- e.g. Amnion Nodosum

Chorangioma of placenta

questions.solution:

questions.text:
Choose the correctly matched pairs.

1. Delusion of grandeur

2. Delusion of infidelity

3. Delusion of love 

4. Nihilistic delusion 

i. Othello syndrome

ii. Cotard syndrome

iii. De Clerambault syndrome

iv. Megalomania
questions.solution:
Option A is correct.

1. Delusion of grandeur

iv. Megalomania

2. Delusion of infidelity

i. Othello syndrome
3. Delusion of love

iii. De Clerambault syndrome
4. Nihilistic delusion

ii. Cotard syndrome

 

Related Pearl: Types of delusions

THE TYPES OF DELUSIONS

Delusion of control

False belief that a person’s will, thoughts, or feelings are being controlled by external forces.

Delusion of grandeur or Megalomania 

Exaggerated conception of one’s importance, power, or identity.

Delusion of infidelity or morbid jealousy or Othello syndrome

False belief that one’s lover is unfaithful. Sometimes called pathological jealousy.

Delusion of love or erotomania

False belief that another person is in love with them. In De Clerambault syndrome, the woman believes that a man, frequently older and of higher status, is in love with her.

Delusion of misidentification 

Capgras syndrome: Belief that a familiar person has been replaced by an exact double i.e. an impostor.

Fregoli syndrome: Person holds a delusional belief that different people are in fact a single person who changes his or her appearance or is in disguise.

Nihilistic delusion 

False belief that oneself, others or the world, is non-existent or about to end. When nihilistic delusion is accompanied by ideas concerning bodily function failure e.g. putrefaction of intestine etc, it is called Cotard syndrome.

Delusion of infestation 

False belief that one is infested with small but visible organisms. As a monosymptomatic delusional disorder, this is called Ekbom syndrome. 

Delusion of persecution

The most common delusion. False belief of being harassed or persecuted.

Delusion of poverty

The person strongly believes they are financially incapacitated.

Delusion of reference

False belief that the behavior of others has a particular and unusual significance, usually of a negative nature. The person may falsely feel that others are talking about them (e.g. the people on television are talking to or about the person).  

Delusion of self-accusation

False feeling of remorse and guilt. Seen in depression with psychotic features.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of Atracurium?

choices.text: Competitively blocking the binding of ACh to its receptors
Repetitive stimulation of Ach receptors on muscle end plate
Inhibiting the calcium channel on presynaptic membrane

questions.solution:
Atracurium is a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent. It acts by competitively blocking the binding of acetylcholine to its receptors.

This leads to a decrease in the effect of acetylcholine and thus, neuronal transmission to the muscle does not occur.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing & non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant: 

  • Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant:

Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes)

  • Gantacurium

Short-acting (10-20 minutes)

  • Mivacurium

 Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)

  • Atracurium
  • Cisatracurium
  • Vecuronium
  • Rocuronium

Long-acting (>50 minutes)

  • Pancuronium
  • Doxacurium

questions.text: Which of the following appears hypointense/ dark on both T1 and T2 weighted images on a MRI?
questions.solution:
Ligaments appears hypointense/ dark on both T1 and T2 -weighted MRI.

Dark on T1-weighted image:

  • Increased water, as in edema, tumor, infarction, inflammation, infection, hemorrhage
  • Calcification
  • Flow void

Bright on T1-weighted image: 

  • Fat
  • Subacute hemorrhage
  • Protein-rich fluid
  • Slowly flowing blood

Bright on T2-weighted image: 

  • Increased water, as in edema, tumor, infarction, inflammation, infection, subdural collection

Dark on T2-weighted image: 

  • Calcification, fibrous tissue
  • Protein-rich fluid
  • Flow void

Related Pearl: T1 vs T2 MRI

Structure
T1 image
